translated: Verses of the Elder Monks 13.1
Verses of the Elders🔽The Collection of 33s
The First Chapter
Soṇakoḷivisa
The one who was most austere in the kingdom,
the one who was the king’s chief elephant,
today is most austere in the Dhamma,
Soṇa, who has gone beyond suffering.
Cut off five, abandon five,
and develop five more.
The monk who has gone beyond the five bonds

analyzed: ogha tiṇṇaḥ ti vuccati  unnaḷassa pamattassa
translated: is said to have crossed the flood.🔽For the monk who is puffed up, heedless,
and lives outside,
his virtue, concentration, and wisdom

original: pāripūriṁ na gacchati.🔽Yañhi kiccaṁ apaviddhaṁ,🔽akiccaṁ pana karīyati;
analyzed: pāripūrim na gacchati  yat hi kiccam apaviddha  a kiccam pana karīyati
translated: do not reach fulfillment.🔽If what should be done is neglected🔽and what should not be done is done,
for those who are puffed up and heedless,
their effluents increase.
But for those who are well-composed,
who always have mindfulness immersed in the body,
they don’t pursue what should not be done,
and they are diligent in what should be done.
For those who are mindful and fully aware,
their effluents come to an end.
When the straight path is pointed out,
go on it, don’t turn back.
Urging yourself on,
When your energy is too intense,
The Teacher, unsurpassed in the world,

original: Vīṇopamaṁ karitvā me,🔽dhammaṁ desesi cakkhumā;🔽Tassāhaṁ vacanaṁ sutvā,
analyzed: vīṇā upamam karitvā me  dhammaṃ desesi cakkhumā  tassa aham vacanam sutvā
translated: Having made the simile of the lute,🔽The one with vision taught me the Dhamma.🔽Having heard his words,
I dwelt delighting in his dispensation.
I practiced serenity,
for the attainment of the supreme goal.
The three knowledges were attained,
and the Buddha’s instruction was fulfilled.
For one intent on renunciation,

analyzed: pavivekam ca cetasaḥ  a byāpajja adhimuttassa  upādāna khayassa ca
translated: and for one whose mind is secluded,🔽For one intent on non-harming,🔽and for one who has destroyed clinging,
For one intent on the destruction of craving,
and for one whose mind is without confusion,
Having seen the arising of the sense-spheres,
the mind is fully freed.
For one who is rightly freed,
for a monk whose mind is calm,
There is no more re-becoming,
and nothing more to be done.
Just as a solid mass of rock
is not shaken by the wind,
So forms, tastes, sounds,
smells, and touches,
Pleasant and unpleasant things,
do not disturb one who is steady.
The mind is stilled and detached,
and he contemplates its passing away.”
… The elder Soṇa Koḷivisa …
The thirteenth section is finished.🔽Here is the summary:
Soṇa, Koḷivisa, the elder,
he alone was one of great power;
In the thirteenth section,
here there are thirteen verses.
